content: Oh oh hey welcome to the DM scrap short if
I'm being Scottie Gennady with me today I want to talk about doing different
types of tiles that merge together I'm working on AJ script and I thought it
might be interesting to show you this there's a sandstone cave that leads into
the Crypt so it's a different type of tile the Crypt is more like a
traditional dungeon where the sandstone cave is a cavern pile and it connects to
it leads into the crypts so I've got the cavern pipe pile leading into a dungeon
type tile and there are two differently different types of terrain the cave is
like a sandstone that's a totally different color and the Crypt is like a
vessel black so I want to have some paddle a little bit of a merger of the
two and let's go the table I'll show you how I did that
now here's a sandstone cave entrance and I haven't done any detail on it yet but
I've just painted it I basically done it the basic sandstone texture paint color
and then I've added some flocking to it but I want to kind of have it so it's
kind of it's going into this script a J's crypt as a matter of fact that is a
different type of material but I want to have it transition naturally so what
I've got is I've got the front the cave part and then here it comes into the
crypt and you can see I've got some rubble that matches the sandstone on
there so it looks like it looks like a natural transition
it doesn't just one and in one start so that's a nice little trick you can do
for this type of thing now what I'm going to do now is I'm going to do a
little bit of texture to this to the sandstone and we'll go to the table
we'll do that now with this unlike grey I'm going to use a burnt umber Brown to
give the shame to the sense it's a sandstone it'll be a little
different so I'll do that I'll do the walls and then I'll run some on me I
want to get that now when this does dry I want to give it I'm gonna do the black
shadow on the wall because well it's a shadow so you can see that I'm doing the
dark brown on the rubble and on the tile itself and not the black so but I will
do the black for the shadow so there we go a little bit of detail on there and
now with the with the tomb entrance I want to have these rubbles match the
sandstone so I'll do is I'll do brown on those fill ISM with brown and then I'll
add the sandstone highlight to those my burnt umber has dried on this section
and what I'm going to do is I'm going to use a cinnamon to kind of give it a
highlight so I'll grab that on my flat edged brush and then I'll start going
over some of that alright I'm liking that what I'm gonna do is we will let
this dry for a minute and then I'm gonna have even a lighter
shade to it so look there so there we go now so I've got the cavern this cavern
part finished but I want to do a little bit on the transitional tile because
this this cavern goes into an area that's not the same type of dungeon it's
this vessel crypt okay so I put my my rock on there my flocking and I'm going
to take the same cinnamon and paint the rocks so they match that other tile and
then what I'm gonna do is I'm going to do a little bit of dry brushing
the transition so it seems like there's a little bit of dust and that kind of
thing in that got dragged into this or actually fell into it maybe after the
long lick of time so I'm going to use as a camel color and it's just a bit
lighter than the other the cinnamon so now I'll go over the
rocks you can see how that lifts that out just a touch more and then I'll do
the edge and I'll be a little bit on the floor I have some real few raised areas
on the floor and now give it some depth all right
so I like that now let's bring in our other tile and this is the different
tile here and then I want to hit it with the highlight so that kind of pops off
those stones even more and I'll do a little bit of on the tile itself
all right so I think it's good now we're all set so let me give you a little
closer look there all right so see there's a nice transition between the
two looks like they blend into each other
that's a good way to do tiles that are different types but then run into each
other so after that highlight dries I'm gonna do what I usually do with tiles
like this I'm gonna give it a shadow now all the shading I used on this tile was
burnt umber but I'm gonna use black for the edge and this is this is as always
watered down black and you can even go a little bit on the files if you want
don't get too crazy with it all right there we go so we have a nice shadow on
the walls there and and now we'll move on to the other tile now I'm not gonna
